5.text: Accidents happen because of a culture.

7.text: Every recent big accident such as BP's Texas City and

10.text: Deepwater Horizon disasters, Longford and NASA's

14.text: shuttle disasters has been directly linked to poor

17.text: safety culture. When we look back, it always was

20.text: the culture. Not just the big accidents but most

23.text: of the smaller ones as well. People are trying to

26.text: get the job done - so all too often, they were

28.text: allowed to get away with dangerous behaviours.

31.text: When things go well, like Qantas QF32 or the

34.text: Miracle on the Hudson, we get to see just how big

37.text: a role a positive culture plays in averting disaster.

40.text: Culture plays both ways. So a better culture

43.text: is the place to be especially when danger is

46.text: your business. The best organisations know this.

49.text: They look at their own cultural of safety.

52.text: They ask how they can improve. That is what I want

54.text: to talk about today. My name is Patrick Hudson.

58.text: I was Professor of the Human Factor in Safety at

61.text: Delft University of Technology in the Netherlands

64.text: and have been working in the safety business for

66.text: the last 28 years, mostly in oil and gas,

68.text: aviation, mining and pharmaceuticals. There's a

72.text: list of what makes a good culture culled from

74.text: numerous studies such as Jim Reason's seminal

77.text: study and my own work with companies such as BHP,

80.text: Shell, BP and Exxon. These are, first of all, leadership.

86.text: Leaders are not afraid to do difficult things.

89.text: Everyone knows where leaders stand on managing risks -

91.text: either taking the risks or running them. Secondly, respect.

97.text: Individuals are respected as are the dangers they face.

101.text: Experts are listened to, even when they are low in

104.text: the hierarchy. This leads to being informed.

108.text: Managers know what is really going on and the workforce

112.text: is willing to report their own errors and near misses

115.text: - which is pretty hard for them to say and for

118.text: managers to hear. These create a culture that is mindful.

124.text: Everyone is weary and always ready for the unexpected.

128.text: Also, a respectful culture is one that is just and fair,

134.text: a culture with clear lines between what is acceptable

137.text: and unacceptable, ones that everyone agrees upon.

141.text: What makes it just, is that there are well

143.text: understood consequences, both positive and negative.

147.text: What makes it fair is everyone from top to bottom agrees

151.text: where the lines are drawn and the consequences of

153.text: crossing them. Finally, the organisation is learning.

159.text: Willing to adapt and implement necessary reforms even when

163.text: they feel expensive and even when holy cows have

166.text: to be overthrown based upon what they've learned.

173.text: many clear advantages, not only in safety but

176.text: also commercially. The advantages are that such

179.text: organisations are flexible. They operate according

184.text: to need rather than tradition. Reliable - they

188.text: always deliver on time, on quality, on demand

192.text: because they manage the risks better than anyone

194.text: else. This makes them profitable. All their

199.text: stakeholders benefit. Finally, people like working

205.text: in that sort of organisation. The problem is this

208.text: is a daunting list for leaders. How can they do

211.text: this? Most studies of safety culture wind up with

214.text: something like this, such as the High Reliability

216.text: Organisation program. The problem is that most

220.text: organisations are nowhere near this level and if

222.text: they were, they wouldn't need help and advice.

225.text: Most organisations that want to achieve this list

228.text: need a roadmap. This is what the safety culture

231.text: ladder offers - providing a structure to help

234.text: decide where you are now, where you want to go to

237.text: and support the process of getting there. We can

241.text: describe a sequence of distinct cultures that

243.text: differ in many ways, including how they regard

246.text: safety. First and definitely not a culture of

250.text: safety, is the pathological. Safety seems a

253.text: problem caused by workers. The main driver is the

256.text: business and a desire not to get caught by the

259.text: regulator. Then we have four levels of increasing

266.text: the reactive. Organisations start to take safety

270.text: seriously but only after incidents is there

273.text: action. Whenever they see a problem, they want to

276.text: fix it. Then, we progress to the calculative.

282.text: Safety is driven by management systems with much

285.text: collection of data. Safety is still primarily

288.text: driven by management but all agree, systems are

292.text: the way to go. Beyond that however, there's the

300.text: unexpected is more of a challenge. Workforce

303.text: involvement starts to move the initiative away

306.text: from a purely top-down approach. And finally, generative.

312.text: There is active participation at all levels.

315.text: Safety is part of the business and

317.text: organisations are characterised by chronic unease -

319.text: "We're doing so well. What are we missing?"

325.text: I have learnt that this ladder is very attractive to

328.text: those who want to do their best but it turns out

331.text: to be more difficult to improve than most people imagine,

335.text: which I have to admit can be frustrating,

338.text: especially when the organisation's leaders want to

340.text: get to the top, and quickly - an admirable

344.text: attitude but one that needs to be tempered lest it

348.text: be doomed to failure. The good news is that

351.text: knowing how to proceed, can help to speed things

354.text: up quite a lot. The first lesson people need to

357.text: learn is that fine speeches and motivational

360.text: speakers don't really help. The feel-good factor

363.text: they create usually has a very short half­-life

366.text: and dissipates maybe by the next morning.

372.text: possibly making things worse rather than better.

375.text: The good news however, is that that the motivation

378.text: is already there. In my experience of asking many

381.text: companies in different industries, ranging from

384.text: oil and gas and mining to pharmaceuticals,

387.text: to aircraft engineering, is that people can recognise

390.text: where they are on the ladder and always want to be higher.

393.text: From top to bottom. In all such organisations,

397.text: there's a built-in desire to be better. The problem is

400.text: day-to-day reality. They have good values and impeccable

404.text: attitudes when surveyed but their behaviours are what

407.text: let them down. One of the common simple definition of

410.text: culture is "how we do things round here". This is

414.text: where aspiration meets reality - where the rubber

417.text: meets the road. What I have found does work is

420.text: discovering what they could do or change ie,

423.text: their activities, processes or systems which would first,

427.text: be characteristic of more advanced safety cultures.

430.text: Secondly, be fairly easily be made to be

432.text: how things are done and by using standard

436.text: management skills for ensuring change takes place.

439.text: When people say, "We could certainly do that,"

443.text: then we can use standard management approaches

448.text: nevertheless impact on the culture. If they behave

451.text: this way for long enough, they become what they

453.text: wanted to be. To help in the process of going up

457.text: the ladder, I made a discovery that can help.

460.text: I found talking to many organisations, not only did

464.text: they think they were higher up the ladder than I

466.text: suspected them to be but when challenged they'd

468.text: say, "But we have this in place and that in place,"

471.text: and I realised that they thought having

473.text: things like reporting systems or communication

475.text: strategies in place, was going to be enough.

479.text: Certainly, they were reacting to demands from regulators,

483.text: the industry and internally to be compliant

485.text: with the requirements and often, having

487.text: things in place kept the auditors happy. But I

490.text: realised that actually putting them into operation

493.text: was a distinctly new challenge that will be

495.text: characteristic of having the management system

497.text: actually running. So the first stage was rather

500.text: typical for reactive cultures, while calculative

503.text: cultures actually both have a process and used it.

507.text: For example, a country's aviation regulator set

510.text: up an aircraft accident investigation bureau which

513.text: in turn, put a confidential reporting system in place

516.text: for their aviation industry. At the end of the

518.text: first year, there were two reports. In place? Yes.

523.text: Operational? No. They passed the audit. So putting

528.text: processes and systems in place is what happens

530.text: when a pathological organisation makes the move to

533.text: becoming reactive. Along with this is a tremendous

537.text: commitment to safety, the decision to mend one's

539.text: ways and do the right thing. Here, we already

543.text: measured good attitudes and optimistic beliefs.

546.text: To make the transition from a reactive to a

551.text: putting these processes and systems into operation -

554.text: making them work. But what next? The transition to

558.text: becoming a proactive organisation becomes clear.

561.text: It involves making the processes and systems

564.text: that are now in operation truly effective because

567.text: often they're not, or they no longer have the

569.text: impact that was expected when they were put in place.

573.text: What may have worked at first no longer has the

575.text: effect originally intended after the kick-off effect.

578.text: For instance, the first reports may have a great impact,

581.text: "Wow, do we do that?" but they just become reports

584.text: to be counted, giving numbers to be reported quarterly.

587.text: On the Deepwater Horizon, 110 staff on board were submitting

590.text: an average of over 100 stock cards every day -

593.text: nearly one per person, per day - not that it helped.

597.text: This transition to a proactive culture is hard,

600.text: harder than people imagine, including myself -

603.text: and I'm going to come back to this. Finally, it's essential

606.text: to ensure that what has become a number of effective habits

609.text: generating stellar safety performance as well as

612.text: environmental and quality outcomes, become permanent.

616.text: Only then can we speak of "How we do things around here"

619.text: in ways that mean that the organisation has become

622.text: a true culture of safety. This is when the best habits

626.text: are ingrained so operations are more than safety first.

630.text: Safety is no longer a priority but the true value,

633.text: meaning far more than just an answer in a survey.

637.text: At the generative level, safety overrides the temptations

640.text: for both workers and managers to do it dangerously,

643.text: "just this once". There are challenges to both going

647.text: higher up the ladder and staying there if you got there

649.text: in the first place. The safety ladder has snakes.

652.text: One of these, from my own experience, was when a very

655.text: advanced organisation, an Australian coal mine,

659.text: was taken over by a foreign company that insisted that

661.text: they throw away their old processes that worked really

664.text: well for them and replace them with their own that

667.text: objectively were actually not producing such good

670.text: performance elsewhere for the new owner.

672.text: Fortunately, the culture was strong, the processes

676.text: embedded and they carried on, but quietly.

679.text: Another problem is when success in part of an organisation

682.text: means they no longer get the senior management

684.text: attention that was helping them be good in the first place.

687.text: This can lead to reversion and in the worst case,

689.text: a drop from the top right down to the very bottom.

692.text: The case reported in the Harvard Business Review

695.text: of the Nut Island sewage works in Massachusetts

698.text: that went from the best, to actually pumping

700.text: out raw sewage into Boston Bay, is also a story

704.text: we need to hear. The simple sequence in place,

709.text: in operation, effective, permanent can be

713.text: mapped onto the transitions of the ladder from

715.text: pathological right up to generative, so wherever

719.text: we are, what's stopping us. The first transition

724.text: requires getting out of the pathological mindset.

727.text: I don't want to say a lot about this here,

729.text: but uncompromising regulation, messages from the

732.text: markets or, unfortunately the most frequent impulse,

736.text: a big disaster - Exxon has never been the same

739.text: since the Exxon Valdez - these can be enough

742.text: to get things in place, change attitudes,

745.text: instil some values that this safety stuff is worth taking

747.text: seriously. It is not enough to achieve stellar

751.text: goals but represents the hardest change of all.

755.text: The next stage is still really hard because

757.text: reactive organisations already have good attitudes.

760.text: Their problem is a shortage of managerial

762.text: skill to get the performance they,

764.text: and others might demand of them. The fight is between

768.text: how things get done and the systems that are in

770.text: place but may not be used. This means that the

773.text: major driver has to come from management,

776.text: right from the top. Management has to concentrate

779.text: on ensuring that everyone - and this includes

781.text: top management themselves - gets into the habit

784.text: of doing things the way they say they should.

787.text: They have to have the discipline to keep on using

789.text: processes and systems until they become the norm.

793.text: That's another word for culture. Self-discipline

795.text: has to be applied by senior managers to ensure

798.text: that everyone else becomes disciplined as well.

801.text: This is hard. The temptations to backslide,

805.text: "just this once" are many but disastrous for progress in

812.text: many organisations have done this and are predominantly

815.text: calculative nowadays. They can invariably be

817.text: recognised by their performance as well as how they

819.text: do things. What I have found, time and time again,

824.text: is that the best of these calculative

825.text: organisations recognise that there is such a thing

828.text: as being too system driven and they want to make

831.text: the move to becoming a proactive culture. This is

835.text: where it gets really hard and I find a metaphor

837.text: useful to understand why the transition to a

840.text: proactive culture is so difficult. I see

847.text: calculative organisations as being like caterpillars.

850.text: Steadily munching their way through the leaves,

852.text: very organised and efficient but the caterpillar looks

855.text: up to the sky and sees a beautiful butterfly

857.text: floating past and thinks, "I wish I could be like that."

861.text: Little does the caterpillar know that a caterpillar is the

864.text: resource that's needed. How would you know?

867.text: Where in a caterpillar are the butterfly's wings?

870.text: What do all the legs become? When the caterpillar

872.text: has become large enough, a miracle occurs - pupation,

876.text: when the caterpillar turns into butterfly soup.

879.text: You have all the ingredients. What you need to do

881.text: next is to change to become something completely new.

885.text: The lesson for organisations is that to make

887.text: their safety systems effective, everything has to

890.text: be challenged and re-examined. What was good

892.text: enough for a reactive culture and appeared to

895.text: operate for a calculative one, is no longer good enough.

899.text: What worked to get you there is no longer

901.text: enough to take you further. For instance,

904.text: the knowledge accumulated by a calculative culture,

906.text: aggregated at the corporate centre, has to be

909.text: pushed back out to be used by managers and workers,

914.text: require a radically different sort of training and

917.text: the expansion of roles and responsibilities in a

919.text: proactive organisation. Top management can feel

922.text: comfortable in having got their safety management systems

925.text: to work. Now they'll have to make themselves deliberately

928.text: uncomfortable learning to resist the cry that,

931.text: "It was working fine. Don't change it."

935.text: Let's take an example of an incident database.

938.text: This is crucial for creating an informed culture.

940.text: It is the repository of the reports from

942.text: a reporting culture and provides the data for a

945.text: learning organisation. First, you need to have a

949.text: database available with ways of getting incidents

952.text: in and information out, but people may be loathed

955.text: to report. Investigations may be summary to the

957.text: point of useless except for counting purposes.

960.text: Still, it's in place. Next, you need to operate

963.text: the database by ensuring that people actually put

966.text: incidents and reported hazards into the database.

969.text: This is the discipline senior managers must exercise.

972.text: You also need to train the workforce so

974.text: that people know what's worth reporting and how to

977.text: both investigate and also analyse incidents usefully.

981.text: Often we want, or we even have a confidential

983.text: reporting system required but we have to

986.text: show that reporting leads to change rather than blame,

989.text: if anyone's going to report at all.

991.text: The database and associated processes may,

998.text: To be truly effective, the data inside has to be turned

1001.text: into information. Especially, it must have the opportunity

1004.text: to surprise us, "I didn't know we were working like that"

1008.text: and properly inform our decision-making processes,

1011.text: "Where do we spend our resources?" Not just justifying

1015.text: decisions after the event. Finally, the system has

1026.text: This may all sound unnecessarily complicated but consider

1029.text: that the financial culture has usually got all

1032.text: these facets long in place, in operation and

1035.text: effective for financial information which is more

1038.text: than just the raw finance data. Consider what

1041.text: happens to your expenses claim. Does a change of

1043.text: manager change that system? Maybe a good safety

1046.text: system should learn from the success of the

1049.text: financial systems within organisations. So, what's

1052.text: hard about becoming generative then? Wasn't the

1054.text: hard bit just becoming proactive? In the

1057.text: generative culture all these elements come to fruition.

1060.text: In the proactive culture, the top of the

1062.text: organisation is still driving safety but have

1065.text: created the potential to let those who are the

1067.text: subject matter experts take responsibility and

1070.text: accept it as well. Thinking about generative

1073.text: organisations and the very few I have seen and

1076.text: heard about, I realised that they could be

1078.text: described as saying that the lunatics are running

1081.text: the asylum. Top management stood back and it

1084.text: looked as if they had nothing to do as far as safety

1086.text: was concerned or indeed, in production either.

1089.text: But then I realised that they have the

1091.text: hardest job of all - designing asylums to be run

1094.text: by lunatics. This captures the deck crew on USS

1098.text: Carl Vinson where the officers watched but could

1100.text: not intervene. This was what the General Manager

1103.text: of the coal mine intended when he set up

1105.text: operations so the miners had to use their brains,

1108.text: all day long. This can be hard for senior managers

1113.text: to let others stand out and often take the glory.

1116.text: Pathological leaders use the organisation to

1118.text: polish their glory. Generative leaders glory in

1122.text: the achievements of their workforce. So, when we

1127.text: ask where we are on the ladder, we can pose a number

1130.text: of challenges about the safety processes and systems,

1133.text: and we do safety. "What are you actually doing?",

1136.text: "Are things just in place or in operation?",

1139.text: "How would you know if it was working?",

1141.text: "Is it data or information?", "What would people

1143.text: do if you stopped right now?" A takeover may

1146.text: change everything. A new broom can sweep

1148.text: clean and clean away. "Who's behaviour are

1152.text: we talking about? Is it just the workers, the managers,

1155.text: the executive management or everybody together?"

1159.text: But this shouldn't be that hard. So why don't

1161.text: more people or organisations get to the top

1164.text: of the ladder? People don't believe cultural

1166.text: change is like this. Surely, we have to win hearts

1169.text: and minds? Yes. The best way to win hearts and minds

1173.text: is by proven success by yourselves not by others.

1180.text: what you decided to do. Many organisations however,

1183.text: see strategic planning as having a higher

1185.text: status than mere implementation. Events overtake

1189.text: plans and we discover that the senior management

1192.text: commitment was not as strong as it was during the

1195.text: opening speeches of the culture initiative.

1198.text: Cultural change takes time. Senior managers are

1201.text: impatient and may be moved on before the fruits ripen.

1204.text: It probably takes two years at a minimum to

1206.text: change from old, bad safety habits to new and

1210.text: better ones. Another set of disablers include

1212.text: authoritarian leadership styles who cannot give

1216.text: away hard-earned power - corporate loss of nerve

1219.text: shown by withdrawal of permission to try new things,

1222.text: imposition of top-down control because of a

1225.text: lack of trust, a fear that the workforce will

1227.text: run away and be irresponsible, managerial failure

1231.text: to learn to like bad news - an essential part of

1235.text: their diet, corporate flexibility and possibly

1238.text: regulatory inflexibility as well. The benefits are

1242.text: clear because the kind of organisation that makes

1245.text: it to the proactive level runs better. The people

1248.text: who work enjoy it more, staff turnover is less.

1251.text: Another advantage of the advanced culture is a

1254.text: consequence of increased trust, "You do your job

1257.text: and I'll do mine," that results in reduced

1259.text: supervisory costs and increased flexibility in operation.

1265.text: keep costs down as well but advanced cultures do

1268.text: spend more to glean the maximum information from

1271.text: the few incidents they have. The most important

1275.text: ingredient in moving up the ladder is the

1278.text: commitment and actions of leadership, primarily

1280.text: senior leaders, but also those safety leaders

1283.text: throughout the organisation who together develop

1286.text: the trust that things will be done properly, both

1288.text: top-down and bottom-up. In my next talk I'll cover

1291.text: leadership, safety leadership in particular and how

1295.text: leadership and culture are intimately intertwined.

1298.text: In conclusion, it's possible to climb the

1301.text: ladder but it's hard and probably harder than

1303.text: people expect when they start. The good news is

1306.text: that I have never found anyone who wanted to go

1308.text: down the ladder but lots of people at all levels who

1311.text: wanted to go up. Finally, if you do make it up there,

1317.text: environmentally, socially and you all get
